channel.title: Home on gg
channel.description: Recent content in Home on gg

item.title: Working Locally
item.description: Whether you are working by yourself or with others, the workflow for making changes on your local machine stays the same. This guide is primarily aimed at those who are new to version control, but is also useful for seasoned version control users trying to see how gg stacks up to their current tool.

item.title: Fork and Pull
item.description: The fork and pull model popularized by GitHub is the most common way to use gg. When using this model, the project has a primary repository that only the maintainers of the project have write access to. Contributors make changes by sharing a cloned repository (called the fork) with new branches. Contributors send pull requests to maintainers, who then review the code and merge in the changes.

item.title: Shared Repository
item.description: In the shared repository model, the source of truth is a single shared repository. This pattern is popular with individuals and smaller teams. Each developer clones to a repository on their own machine and makes their changes. When they are ready to share, they push to a branch on the single shared repository. If they are using pull requests, each change goes onto a distinct branch for review. Otherwise, usually commits go directly to the default branch (usually master).

item.title: Gerrit
item.description: Some popular open source projects use Gerrit, a code review tool, to manage code contributions. Examples include Go, Android, and Chromium. Gerrit has a somewhat unique model for receiving changes that involves amending commits and pushing to specially formatted ref names. Developers using Gerrit usually build shortcuts on top of Git to manage this complexity, but gg has built-in support for Gerrit. gg makes working with Gerrit as easy as other Git workflows.

item.title: gg add
item.description: add the specified files on the next commit

item.title: gg branch
item.description: list or manage branches

item.title: gg clone
item.description: make a copy of an existing repository

item.title: gg commit
item.description: commit the specified files or all outstanding changes

item.title: gg diff
item.description: diff repository (or selected files)

item.title: gg evolve
item.description: sync with Gerrit changes in upstream

item.title: gg gerrithook
item.description: install or uninstall Gerrit change ID hook

item.title: gg histedit
item.description: interactively edit revision history

item.title: gg init
item.description: create a new repository in the given directory

item.title: gg log
item.description: show revision history of entire repository or files

item.title: gg mail
item.description: creates or updates a Gerrit change

item.title: gg merge
item.description: merge another revision into working directory

item.title: gg pull
item.description: pull changes from the specified source

item.title: gg push
item.description: push changes to the specified destination

item.title: gg rebase
item.description: move revision (and descendants) to a different branch

item.title: gg remove
item.description: remove the specified files on the next commit

item.title: gg revert
item.description: restore files to their checkout state

item.title: gg status
item.description: show changed files in the working directory

item.title: gg update
item.description: update working directory (or switch revisions)

item.title: gg upstream
item.description: query or set upstream branch
